skill.author: Dicklesworthstone

security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation and text prompts. No executable code, file access, network calls, or command execution. Safe for distribution.

content.user_title: Polish web app UI/UX with iterative enhancement workflow
content.value_statement: Your web app looks decent but lacks world-class polish. Use this iterative workflow to incrementally enhance UI/UX across desktop and mobile, achieving Stripe-level visual quality through multiple focused passes.
actual_capabilities: Provides exact prompts for UI/UX enhancement
Separate optimization strategies for desktop and mobile
Best practices for visual polish techniques
Integration tips with modern tech stacks (Next.js, React, Tailwind)
Progress tracking methodology for cumulative improvements
limitations: Does not modify code directly; provides prompts to guide AI agents
Requires existing working app with basic styling already in place
Does not fix bugs or broken functionality
Cannot establish design systems from scratch

use_cases.title: Elevate existing web apps
use_cases.description: Transform decent-looking web applications into polished, professional interfaces following industry best practices.

use_cases.title: Refine visual polish iteratively
use_cases.description: Apply systematic improvements through multiple passes to achieve high-quality visual presentation.

use_cases.title: Guide AI agents for UI work
use_cases.description: Provide AI agents with effective prompts to make meaningful UI/UX enhancements automatically.

prompt_templates.title: Main Polish Prompt
prompt_templates.prompt: I still think there are strong opportunities to enhance the UI/UX look and feel and to make everything work better and be more intuitive, user-friendly, visually appealing, polished, slick, and world class in terms of following UI/UX best practices like those used by Stripe, don't you agree? And I want you to carefully consider desktop UI/UX and mobile UI/UX separately while doing this and hyper-optimize for both separately to play to the specifics of each modality. I'm looking for true world-class visual appeal, polish, slickness, etc. that makes people gasp at how stunning and perfect it is in every way. Use ultrathink.

prompt_templates.title: General Scrutiny
prompt_templates.prompt: Great, now I want you to super carefully scrutinize every aspect of the application workflow and implementation and look for things that just seem sub-optimal or even wrong/mistaken to you, things that could very obviously be improved from a user-friendliness and intuitiveness standpoint, places where our UI/UX could be improved and polished to be slicker, more visually appealing, and more premium feeling and just ultra high quality, like Stripe-level apps.

prompt_templates.title: Mobile Optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Focus specifically on mobile UI/UX optimization. Consider touch target sizes, responsive breakpoints, mobile-specific navigation, gesture support, and mobile performance. What changes would make this app exceptional on mobile devices?

prompt_templates.title: Desktop Optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Focus specifically on desktop UI/UX optimization. Consider keyboard navigation, hover states, multi-column layouts, sidebar navigation, and power user shortcuts. What changes would make this app exceptional on desktop?

output_examples.input: Apply UI/UX polish to my dashboard application
output: Improved shadow and depth effects for better visual hierarchy
Consistent border radius and spacing across components
Enhanced hover and focus states for interactive elements
Better loading and empty state designs
Touch-friendly button sizes for mobile devices

best_practices: Run multiple iterations (10+) for cumulative improvements rather than expecting dramatic changes in a single pass
Separate desktop and mobile optimization to avoid compromises that work poorly on both platforms
Review AI-generated changes carefully to ensure no regressions in functionality
anti_patterns: Using this workflow on broken or buggy apps instead of fixing issues first
Applying polish prompts when no basic styling or design system exists
Skipping iterations when changes seem minor; small improvements compound significantly

faq.question: Which AI models work best with this skill?
faq.answer: Claude Code with Opus 4.5 and Codex with GPT 5.2 (High/Extra-High reasoning) work excellently. Gemini CLI also produces good results.

faq.question: How many iterations are recommended?
faq.answer: Plan for 10 or more iterations. Each pass adds incremental improvements that compound dramatically over time.

faq.question: Can multiple agents work on polish simultaneously?
faq.answer: Yes, multiple agents can work together. Use file reservations to avoid conflicts and focus on different areas of the application.

faq.question: What data does this skill access?
faq.answer: This is a prompt-only skill that provides text guidance. It does not access files, networks, or execute any code.

faq.question: When should I not use this workflow?
faq.answer: Do not use on broken apps, when starting from scratch, or when no basic styling exists. This is for refining working applications.

faq.question: How does this compare to complete design overhauls?
faq.answer: This workflow enhances already-working apps incrementally. Complete overhauls require establishing design systems first, which this does not do.
